Thiago de Carvalho Moretti

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/2409977843121616
  • Última atualização do currículo em 17/05/2019

Possuo bacharelado e licenciatura em Ciências Biológicas pela Universidade Estadual de Campinas (2002), mestrado em Parasitologia também pela Universidade Estadual de Campinas (2006), doutorado em Zoologia pela Universidade Estadual Paulista Júlio de Mesquita Filho (Instituto de Biociências de Botucatu) (2011) e pós-doutorado pela Universidade Estadual de Campinas (2016). Meus principais interesses são biologia, ecologia e comportamento de artrópodes de importância médico-veterinária e forense, especialmente Diptera e Hymenoptera. (Texto informado pelo autor)

Projetos de pesquisa
2014 - 2016
FAPESP (2012/02027-0): Behavioral and interactive dynamics, and intraspecific variability in the social wasp Agelaia pallipes (Hymenoptera, Vespidae, Polistinae)
Descrição: Agelaia pallipes is said to be highly abundant at vertebrate carcasses and is very aggressive toward carrion flies, which suggests that this wasp may be much more important in carrion decomposition than previously thought. However, very little is known about the actual forensic importance of A. pallipes, whose records at carrion are mainly based on anecdotal evidence. The project aimed to elucidate the possible forensic utilization of A. pallipes. To this end, we examined the behavioral dynamics and the relationships among A. pallipes and other species of insects regularly found at decomposing vertebrate carrion in tropical environments.
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Thiago de Carvalho Moretti - Integrante / Arício Xavier Linhares - Coordenador.
Financiador(es): Fundação de Amparo à Pesquisa do Estado de São Paulo - Bolsa.
2006 - 2011
FAPESP (06/60504-9): Population dynamics and ecological modelling of flies of forensic importance
Descrição: We addressed basic aspects of the ecology of insects of forensic importance in urban, rural, and forest areas in southeastern Brazil, aiming to encourage specialists to direct their attention toward gathering the data needed to better implement forensic entomology in Brazil. The project was divided into three main areas: (1) population dynamics and spatial-temporal mathematical modelling of the most abundant species of blow flies in the country; (2) Specific information needed for actions on taxonomic groups that are still neglected in the forensic context; and (3) Statistical modelling based on the determination of the season of death.
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Thiago de Carvalho Moretti - Integrante / Patrícia Jacqueline Thyssen - Integrante / Wesley Augusto Conde Godoy - Coordenador.
Financiador(es): Fundação de Amparo à Pesquisa do Estado de São Paulo - Bolsa.
2005 - 2010
THEMATIC GRANT FAPESP (04/08544-0): Forensic entomology: the use of arthropods to determine time, place, cause, and circumstances of death
Descrição: Accurate estimation of the postmortem interval based on the life cycle of necrophagous insects requires their correct identification and knowledge of the variables that affect their development and behavior. This project aimed to study the variability, population dynamics and the effect of toxic substances on the rates of development of blow flies of forensic importance in Brazil.
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Thiago de Carvalho Moretti - Integrante / Patrícia Jacqueline Thyssen - Integrante / Wesley Augusto Conde Godoy - Integrante / Arício Xavier Linhares - Coordenador.
Financiador(es): Fundação de Amparo à Pesquisa do Estado de São Paulo - Bolsa.
2003 - 2006
CAPES: Insects on decomposing carcasses of small rodents in a secondary forest in Southeastern Brazil
Descrição: The decomposition of small carcasses in the open is frequently neglected, although it may provide information of forensic importance. This project describes an experimental study of arthropod species associated with carcasses of mice and rats. Four carcasses were left inside iron cages in sunlit and shady areas in a secondary forest in southeastern Brazil twice each season for four seasons (16 carcasses of each rodent species). The carcasses were removed when arthropod visitation ceased. The visiting and colonizing invertebrates were collected daily and identified. Immatures were also collected and reared in the laboratory for precise identification. Our results indicate that the frequency of occurrence of these arthropods was positively associated with carcass size (mouse or rat); no marked insect succession on the carcasses occurred; and the diversity of calliphorid and sarcophagid flies on the carcasses was high, irrespective of season.
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Thiago de Carvalho Moretti - Integrante / Odair Benedito Ribeiro - Coordenador.
Financiador(es): Coordenação de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior - Bolsa.
